editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

A SERMON: DELIVERED At SALEM, January 14, 1796, OCCASIONED BY THE Execution of HENRY BLACKBURN, ON THAT DAY, For the Murder of GEORGE WILKINSON.

q.p: For we mu≈øt all appear before the Judgment Seat of CHRIST, that every one may receive the things done in his body, according to that he hath done, whether it be good or bad.

div.p: AS the doctrine of a future ≈øtate of retribution is the principal ≈øupport of piety and virtue, the great and univer≈øal importance of it mu≈øt be obvious. And that this is a doctrine "worthy of all acceptation," we have the concurrent te≈øtimonies of natural and revealed religion.
Our text leads us to con≈øider‚ÄîThe certainty of a future judgment‚ÄîSome of the peculiarities of this judgment, as revealed in the go≈øpel‚ÄîAnd the purpo≈øes for which God hath appointed it.
In regard to the certainty of a future ≈øtate of retribution, let it be ob≈øerved,

That the judgment we pa≈øs upon our own actions, or that faculty by which we di≈øcover the difference between good and evil, is the foundation of many of
our mo≈øt plea≈øing hopes, and of our mo≈øt di≈øquieting fears. The ≈øatisfactions which accompany a life of innocence, are greatly increa≈øed by the expectation of a future recompence; and the terrors of a guilty con≈øcience as greatly enhanced.

And we ≈øee, in many in≈øtances, that the di≈øpen≈øations of Providence in the pre≈øent ≈øtate, are promi≈øcuous and unequal. No certain conclu≈øions can be drawn from them, in regard to the virtue or the vice of men. The righteous often ≈øuffer, and for being righteous: And the wicked pro≈øper, and pro≈øper through their wickedne≈øs.

And although the wi≈øe and con≈øiderate in all ages, from a conviction that virtue was excellent in it≈øelf, and that vice was pernicious in its own nature, have endeavored to reward the former, and to puni≈øh the latter, according to their re≈øpective merits; yet no human laws have ever been able to effect the≈øe mo≈øt de≈øirable purpo≈øes. No human tribunal can inve≈øtigate the ≈øecret emotions of the heart, the ≈øource from which all our actions proceed; and in proportion to the relation which they bear to this fountain, they de≈øerve either cen≈øure, or prai≈øe. The ≈øpecious hypocrite may come forward, and challenge the ≈øevere≈øt ≈øcrutiny, while the fear of a di≈øcovery has led him to commit his vile enormities in the dark. But, that impartial ju≈øtice may be di≈øpen≈øed, the motives and intentions of the agent mu≈øt be known. The rich, who, of their abundance ca≈øt much into the trea≈øury, will undoubtedly receive their reward; and yet, the poor widow's two mites may entitle her to a much greater recompence.

Should the internal ≈øatisfactions which accompany a virtuous life, and the mi≈øeries which commonly overtake the wicked, be urged, as an adequate reward to the former, and a ≈øufficient puni≈øhment to the latter; it may be a≈øked, whether any degree of external affluence, in addition to the plea≈øures which flow from a good con≈øcience, ≈øeparate from the views of eternity, would be deemed by a wi≈øe man, an adequate recompence for the exqui≈øite ≈øufferings with which the inflexibly virtuous are ≈øometimes called to ≈øtruggle?

As the≈øe inequalities have been from the beginning of the world, we have all rea≈øon to ≈øuppo≈øe, that they will continue unto the end of it. And from this ≈øtate of things, it is natural to conclude, that there will be a future ≈øtate of retribution, in which all the≈øe inequalities will be rectified, and impartial ju≈øtice di≈øpen≈øed to every man.

And this has been the prevailing opinion, in every age, and in every nation. It is true, that one ≈øect of philo≈øophers among the heathen, and ≈øome among the Jews, denied the re≈øurrection of the dead; but tho≈øe characters were not very numerous; they bore ≈øcarce any kind of proportion to the body of the people, the great multitude, who received the doctrine of a future judgment. On no other principle can we account for the wor≈øhip of the dead; and for the animated de≈øcriptions which the poets have given of the Ely≈øian fields: In which all the virtuous are repre≈øented in a ≈øtate of happine≈øs, and in the enjoyment of the fruits of their pa≈øt labors: While the wicked are excluded tho≈øe happy abodes, and con≈øigned to the regions of wo and mi≈øery forever. And although the rewards and puni≈øhments a≈ø≈øigned
to the≈øe characters, in the future world, are very different in their nature, from tho≈øe which revelation has taught us to expect hereafter, and fall infinitely below them; yet they are ≈øtrongly expre≈ø≈øive of the general opinion concerning the doctrine before us. The Apo≈øtle, in his addre≈øs to the Gentiles, ob≈øerves, that, "the invi≈øible things of him," (God) "from the creation of the world, are clearly ≈øeen, being under≈øtood by the things which are made, even his eternal power and Godhead. So that they are without excu≈øe, becau≈øe that, when they knew God, they glorified him not as God."

But, although the religion of nature taught men to expect a future ≈øtate of retribution, in which they would be rewarded and puni≈øhed, according to their re≈øpective de≈øerts, (and the evidences of this great doctrine have been confirmed by every revelation which God has given of him≈øelf), yet, it gave no intimations of the circum≈øtances which would attend it. For the≈øe mo≈øt ≈øolemn and intere≈øting di≈øcoveries, we are indebted to the revelation of Je≈øus Chri≈øt; through whom, "life and immortality" are "brought to light:" i. e. more fully and clearly revealed.

The fir≈øt of the≈øe peculiar and important di≈øcoveries which I ≈øhall mention, is this,‚ÄîThat there will be a DAY, on which all the generations of men, will be gathered together, in one great and general a≈ø≈øembly, to receive the re≈øpective rewards of their pa≈øt behavior.

"When the Son of man ≈øhall come in his glory, then ≈øhall be gathered before him all nations‚ÄîGod hath appointed a DAY, in which he will judge the world in righteou≈øne≈øs‚ÄîBut of that DAY and hour,
knoweth no man, not even the Son." This is one of tho≈øe "≈øecret things" which "belong to God." But we are informed, that this judgment will take place "at the end of the world," an indefinite period; and which may be much nearer than we apprehend! And when it ≈øhall commence, we are a≈ø≈øured, that it will be accompanied by a univer≈øal re≈øurrection‚Äîof all who in this world have ever ta≈øted death.

"We mu≈øt all appear before the judgment ≈øeat of Chri≈øt," &c. "Verily, verily, I ≈øay unto you, the hour is coming, and even now is, when the dead ≈øhall hear the voice of the Son of God, and they that hear him ≈øhall live."‚Äî"Marvel not at this, for the hour is coming, in which all that are in the graves ≈øhall hear his voice, and ≈øhall come forth, they that have done good, unto the re≈øurrection of life, and they that have done evil, unto the re≈øurrection of damnation."
And immediately after this general re≈øurrection, we are informed, the world which we now inhabit will appear all in flames, and be utterly de≈øtroyed by fire.

"The Lord Je≈øus ≈øhall be revealed from heaven in flaming fire, taking vengeance on them who know not God, and who obey not the go≈øpel of our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt." "The day of the Lord will come as a thief in the night, in which the heavens ≈øhall pa≈øs away in a great noi≈øe, and the elements ≈øhall melt with fervent heat. The earth al≈øo, and all that therein is, ≈øhall be burned up. Seeing then, that all the≈øe things are to be di≈ø≈øolved, what manner of per≈øons ought we to be, in all holy conver≈øation and godline≈øs!"

Another circum≈øtance concerning this future judgment, revealed in the go≈øpel, re≈øpects the per≈øon, to
whom the judiciary powers of that great and ≈øolemn day are committed. And this is the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt him≈øelf. The per≈øon who once appeared in this world, in the form of a ≈øervant, and to ≈øave ≈øinners, although "the Lord of life and glory"‚Äî"who went about doing good"‚Äîand after a life of the pure≈øt benevolence, and of un≈øpotted innocence, "was taken, and by wicked hands, crucified and ≈ølain. But God rai≈øed him up."

"The Father judgeth no man, but hath committed all judgment to the Son.‚ÄîIt is Je≈øus that is ordained of God to be the judge of quick and dead‚ÄîGod will judge the world in righteou≈øne≈øs, by that man Je≈øus Chri≈øt, whom he hath appointed."

In ≈øome pa≈ø≈øages of ≈øcripture, God him≈øelf is ≈øaid to be the judge of all the earth, and who will do right‚Äî and that he will reward every man according to his deeds; "To them who by patient continuance in well doing, ≈øeek for glory, and honor, and immortality, eternal life; but unto them that are contentious, indignation and wrath, tribulation and angui≈øh upon every ≈øoul of man that doeth evil." But the≈øe texts may be reconciled with the former, when we con≈øider, that the future judgment will commence on the day appointed by God; and that all the tran≈øactions of it will be managed by his Son; to whom he has delegated his authority and power; and who will perform all the duties of that great and ≈øolemn office, in perfect obedience to the will of his Father.
Another peculiarity, and which de≈øerves our mo≈øt ≈øerious attention, is the manner in which he will appear upon that ≈øolemn occa≈øion.

"He ≈øhall come in his own glory, in the glory of God, and in the glory of his holy angels‚Äîhe ≈øhall ≈øit upon the throne of his glory, and all nations ≈øhall be gathered before him. And he ≈øhall ≈øeparate them, one from the other, as a ≈øhepherd divideth his ≈øheep from the goats. The Lord him≈øelf ≈øhall de≈øcend from heaven with a ≈øhout, with the voice of the archangel, and with the trump of God. The dead in Chri≈øt ≈øhall ri≈øe fir≈øt, and they that are alive ≈øhall be changed, and caught up to meet the Lord in the air."

Further, the go≈øpel of Je≈øus Chri≈øt di≈øclo≈øes the purpo≈øes of God, in the appointment of this future judgment: namely, That his wi≈ødom, ju≈øtice, goodne≈øs and mercy, may be univer≈øally acknowledged and magnified‚ÄîThat all the ungodly may be convinced "of all their hard ≈øpeeches ≈øpoken again≈øt him"‚Äî And that the glory of the great Judge may be mo≈øt illu≈øtriou≈øly di≈øplayed‚Äî"That all men ≈øhould honor the Son, even as they honor the Father"‚ÄîBecau≈øe "thou ha≈øt loved righteou≈øne≈øs and hated iniquity, therefore God, even thy God, hath anointed thee with the oil of gladne≈øs above thy fellows"‚Äîbe≈øtowed the highe≈øt and mo≈øt di≈øtingui≈øhed honors upon him, as a peculiar mark of his approbation‚Äîand appointed him to the important office of Judge, both of quick and dead, "becau≈øe he was the ≈øon of man"‚ÄîTo quiet our fears and apprehen≈øions on that great day, when we ≈øhall behold, in the per≈øon of our Judge, the greate≈øt benefactor and friend of the human race‚Äîone made like unto our≈øelves‚Äîacquainted with all the imperfections of our nature, and di≈øpo≈øed to pity and compa≈ø≈øionate our weakne≈øs.

"It behoved him to be made like unto his brethren, that he might be a merciful and faithful High Prie≈øt. For we have not an High Prie≈øt, which cannot be touched with the feeling of our infirmities."

And here, it may be ob≈øerved, that there is nothing in any of the≈øe peculiar di≈øcoveries of the go≈øpel, concerning a future judgment, incon≈øi≈øtent with the principles of natural religion. A Being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of almighty power can gather together all nations on that great day, as ea≈øily as di≈øpo≈øe the individuals of which this numerous a≈ø≈øembly is compo≈øed to meet together on the pre≈øent very melancholy occa≈øion.

And there can be no ab≈øurdity in believing, that the Being who fir≈øt gave us life can reanimate the bodies which we now po≈ø≈øe≈øs, and clothe them with fre≈øh powers of life and ≈øen≈øibility, after they have laid ever ≈øo long a period in the graves.

Let us now attend to a few reflections, which ari≈øe from this mo≈øt intere≈øting and important of all ≈øubjects.
And Fir≈øt,

Allowing that we know not the nature, nor the proportion of the rewards and puni≈øhments to be di≈øpen≈øed in a future ≈øtate; yet, this is certain, the go≈øpel has repre≈øented them, and the ≈øolemnities of a future judgment, in the ≈øtronge≈øt light: and in ≈øuch a manner, as to excite the mo≈øt plea≈øing hopes in the virtuous; and the mo≈øt awful apprehen≈øions in the wicked.

"Then ≈øhall the King ≈øay unto them on his right hand, come ye ble≈ø≈øed of my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world.‚ÄîThen ≈øhall he ≈øay unto them on his left hand, depart from me, ye cur≈øed, into everla≈øting fire prepared for the devil and his angels."

Again. From the certainty and circum≈øtances of a future judgment, how great mu≈øt be the ab≈øurdity of di≈ø≈øimulation! On that day, "when the ≈øecrets of all hearts ≈øhall be di≈øclo≈øed," the hope of the hypocrite will peri≈øh. None of tho≈øe arts and ≈øubtilties which he once practi≈øed in the world, and with ≈øucce≈øs, will then avail him.
